article:
I first met Annie Mae, a maid  , at my parents-in-laws' in 1959. She prepared and       _  meals in her
quiet, gentle way and then returned to the kitchen to read her Bible (<<>> ) while we   _  .
She was a devoted Christian. I found this increasingly true  even though  I came to know her more by observation than by conversation.
My husband and I   _  visited his parents. Each time I saw her eating  _  , reading her Bible, I wanted to sit down with her and
just talk.  _  , whites didn't do
that with blacks then, and I had to  _  the practice.
In 1965, I decided to   _  the furniture and return to my home state with my two  _  when my husband wanted a divorce  .
Annie Mae asked if she could buy the boys'   _  . When I answered  _  ,
she asked the price. Then, she asked if she could  _  a little money each month. She was  _  , and I knew her well.
Then each month, an envelope   _  us from Annie Mae with 2 or 3 dollars. A year passed. Annie
Mae's  _  payment arrived
along with the following note:
Dear Mrs. Holladay,
I am sending you my last payment of three dollars for the beds   in full  . I
told my two sons they could now put the beds  _  and sleep in them, for they are now paid for and
rightfully  belong to  us.Thank
you for your  _  .
Annie Mae
I read the note two or three times, my eyes filled with tears. Had I only known earlier, I would have said, "Use them now. Don't   _  until you pay
for them."
